values.description:
Issue #464 was recently found to have regressed, and @hsu added a fix in pull request #673. This pull request targets that fix to the 1.9 branch.

Issue #803 is related to a warning on osx about the string literals in [test/data/pr2_state_log_expected.h](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/90d25760b578980af4a88eeb0ceb38d92265142e/test/data/pr2_state_log_expected.h?at=default), which are larger than the 65536 bytes that C++ compilers are required to support. My proposed fix is to compute and compare sha1 hashes of expected strings. It was easily implemented by piping the command output to `shasum`. It can also be done using boost, but this was more concise.

I've also backported a fix for the `ContactSensor.StackTestODE` test to make Jenkins happy.
values.title: Fixes for 1.9: #464 regression, #803, and ContactSensor.StackTestODE

summary.raw:
Issue #464 was recently found to have regressed, and @hsu added a fix in pull request #673. This pull request targets that fix to the 1.9 branch.

Issue #803 is related to a warning on osx about the string literals in [test/data/pr2_state_log_expected.h](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/90d25760b578980af4a88eeb0ceb38d92265142e/test/data/pr2_state_log_expected.h?at=default), which are larger than the 65536 bytes that C++ compilers are required to support. My proposed fix is to compute and compare sha1 hashes of expected strings. It was easily implemented by piping the command output to `shasum`. It can also be done using boost, but this was more concise.

I've also backported a fix for the `ContactSensor.StackTestODE` test to make Jenkins happy.
summary.html:
Issue #464 was recently found to have regressed, and @hsu added a fix in pull request #673. This pull request targets that fix to the 1.9 branch.

Issue #803 is related to a warning on osx about the string literals in test/data/pr2_state_log_expected.h, which are larger than the 65536 bytes that C++ compilers are required to support. My proposed fix is to compute and compare sha1 hashes of expected strings. It was easily implemented by piping the command output to shasum. It can also be done using boost, but this was more concise.

I've also backported a fix for the ContactSensor.StackTestODE test to make Jenkins happy.

We set the variable of ```HAVE_FFMPEG``` in our SearchForStuff cmake file as:

Do not run the test if proper support is not found.

values.description:
This is the implementation of a suggestion made by @gerkey in pull request [#687](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/687/terrain-paging-support-for-rendering).

The idea is that a new directory is created the first time that you load a new terrain with paging enabled. The next times, the generated terrain files will be loaded, instead of regenerating the subterrains again.

A new file with the SHA1 hash of the image's heighmap is stored in the terrain directory. This hash is compared with the SHA1 of the heightmap to check if the terrain has been modified.
values.title: Caching generated terrain files

summary.raw:
This is the implementation of a suggestion made by @gerkey in pull request [#687](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/687/terrain-paging-support-for-rendering).

The idea is that a new directory is created the first time that you load a new terrain with paging enabled. The next times, the generated terrain files will be loaded, instead of regenerating the subterrains again.

A new file with the SHA1 hash of the image's heighmap is stored in the terrain directory. This hash is compared with the SHA1 of the heightmap to check if the terrain has been modified.
summary.html:
This is the implementation of a suggestion made by @gerkey in pull request #687.

The idea is that a new directory is created the first time that you load a new terrain with paging enabled. The next times, the generated terrain files will be loaded, instead of regenerating the subterrains again.

A new file with the SHA1 hash of the image's heighmap is stored in the terrain directory. This hash is compared with the SHA1 of the heightmap to check if the terrain has been modified.

values.description:
In response to issue #836 and probably useful in some other situations as our testing suite is growing with the time.

I've moved all our cmake testing macros to **GazeboTestUtils.cmake**. In **GazeboUtils.cmake** they are declared empty, so we don't need to modify each CMakeLists.txt, and they are redeclared on the presence of True in  the ```ENABLE_TEST_COMPILATION``` (which for backwards compatibility is on by default) by including the GazeboTestUtils.cmake file.

I've also starting a new section in the README file to document all these building options.
values.title: Support for ENABLE_TESTS_COMPILATION cmake parameter

summary.raw:
In response to issue #836 and probably useful in some other situations as our testing suite is growing with the time.

I've moved all our cmake testing macros to **GazeboTestUtils.cmake**. In **GazeboUtils.cmake** they are declared empty, so we don't need to modify each CMakeLists.txt, and they are redeclared on the presence of True in  the ```ENABLE_TEST_COMPILATION``` (which for backwards compatibility is on by default) by including the GazeboTestUtils.cmake file.

I've also starting a new section in the README file to document all these building options.
summary.html:
In response to issue #836 and probably useful in some other situations as our testing suite is growing with the time.

I've moved all our cmake testing macros to GazeboTestUtils.cmake. In GazeboUtils.cmake they are declared empty, so we don't need to modify each CMakeLists.txt, and they are redeclared on the presence of True in the ENABLE_TEST_COMPILATION (which for backwards compatibility is on by default) by including the GazeboTestUtils.cmake file.

I've also starting a new section in the README file to document all these building options.

values.description:
problem before was that if a model is below the laser scan, gui mouse picking doesn't work, and if the model is above the laser scan, it doesn't always work too.
I changed the GZ_VISIBILITY_NOT_SELECTABLE flag to GZ_VISIBILITY_SELECTABLE, which is more intuitive, otherwise it takes more bitwise operations to get the desired results.
values.title: Fix mouse picking for cases where visuals overlap with the laser

summary.raw:
problem before was that if a model is below the laser scan, gui mouse picking doesn't work, and if the model is above the laser scan, it doesn't always work too.
I changed the GZ_VISIBILITY_NOT_SELECTABLE flag to GZ_VISIBILITY_SELECTABLE, which is more intuitive, otherwise it takes more bitwise operations to get the desired results.
summary.html: problem before was that if a model is below the laser scan, gui mouse picking doesn't work, and if the model is above the laser scan, it doesn't always work too. I changed the GZ_VISIBILITY_NOT_SELECTABLE flag to GZ_VISIBILITY_SELECTABLE, which is more intuitive, otherwise it takes more bitwise operations to get the desired results.

values.description:
Before compiling, uncomment [gazebo/gui/MainWindow.cc:1086](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/c20a738814b10cb9fe967053677294bbc806e1d9/gazebo/gui/MainWindow.cc?at=model_editor_part1#cl-1086) to enable the model editor.

Part 1:

Features include enabling users to:

- add simple shapes, and import custom meshes as parts (links) to a model

- Add joints to the model

- double click on a hotspot on the joint to configure its properties.

A part inspector for configuring parts will be in the next pull request.
values.title: Model editor Part 1 - part and joint creation

summary.raw:
Before compiling, uncomment [gazebo/gui/MainWindow.cc:1086](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/c20a738814b10cb9fe967053677294bbc806e1d9/gazebo/gui/MainWindow.cc?at=model_editor_part1#cl-1086) to enable the model editor.

Part 1:

Features include enabling users to:

- add simple shapes, and import custom meshes as parts (links) to a model

- Add joints to the model

- double click on a hotspot on the joint to configure its properties.

A part inspector for configuring parts will be in the next pull request.
summary.html:
Before compiling, uncomment gazebo/gui/MainWindow.cc:1086 to enable the model editor.

Part 1:

Features include enabling users to:

  • add simple shapes, and import custom meshes as parts (links) to a model

  • Add joints to the model

  • double click on a hotspot on the joint to configure its properties.

A part inspector for configuring parts will be in the next pull request.

values.description:
This was partially removed in a previous pull request. This resulted in atlas spewing a lot of messages:


```
#!c++

Warning [ODEJoint.cc:1103] GetForceTorque: forgot to set <provide_feedback>?
Warning [ODEJoint.cc:1103] GetForceTorque: forgot to set <provide_feedback>?
Warning [ODEJoint.cc:1103] GetForceTorque: forgot to set <provide_feedback>?
```

This PR completely removes the provide feedback variable.

values.description:
This commit fixes issue #849.

In GetSignalStrength(), the transmitter and receiver points cannot be the same. We use GetIntersection() and this method triggers an assertion in Bullet if the points are the same. Fixed by just adding 0.00001 to Z component of the receiver pos.

Normally, this should only happen during the rendering of a wireless transmitter sensor. A grid of points are used to compute the signal strength for each point for a given transmitter. Transmitter and receiver should not be at the same exact position during normal operation.
values.title: Fix issue #849

summary.raw:
This commit fixes issue #849.

In GetSignalStrength(), the transmitter and receiver points cannot be the same. We use GetIntersection() and this method triggers an assertion in Bullet if the points are the same. Fixed by just adding 0.00001 to Z component of the receiver pos.

Normally, this should only happen during the rendering of a wireless transmitter sensor. A grid of points are used to compute the signal strength for each point for a given transmitter. Transmitter and receiver should not be at the same exact position during normal operation.
summary.html:
This commit fixes issue #849.

In GetSignalStrength(), the transmitter and receiver points cannot be the same. We use GetIntersection() and this method triggers an assertion in Bullet if the points are the same. Fixed by just adding 0.00001 to Z component of the receiver pos.

Normally, this should only happen during the rendering of a wireless transmitter sensor. A grid of points are used to compute the signal strength for each point for a given transmitter. Transmitter and receiver should not be at the same exact position during normal operation.

values.description:
The propshop needs 4 pictures for each model. This pull-request contains a plugin and ruby script that will automatically generate these images.

I found that OGRE <1.9 does not allow anti-aliasing in texture buffers. I put in the necessary changes to support OGRE 1.9, which will create nicer images. Ogre 1.9 is not mandatory.

To try the ruby script:

`gzprop <model_directory>`

For example:

`gzprop ~/.gazebo/models/pr2`

A tarball should be created in your current directory that contains the model and a set of images in a `meta` subdirectory.

This PR is  [ABI/API compatible](http://gazebosim.org/compat_reports/pr_734.html) with gazebo-2.0. The goal would be to put this into gazebo-2.1.
values.title: Plugin to create pictures for thepropshop.org

The propshop needs 4 pictures for each model. This pull-request contains a plugin and ruby script that will automatically generate these images.

I found that OGRE <1.9 does not allow anti-aliasing in texture buffers. I put in the necessary changes to support OGRE 1.9, which will create nicer images. Ogre 1.9 is not mandatory.

To try the ruby script:

`gzprop <model_directory>`

For example:

`gzprop ~/.gazebo/models/pr2`

A tarball should be created in your current directory that contains the model and a set of images in a `meta` subdirectory.

This PR is  [ABI/API compatible](http://gazebosim.org/compat_reports/pr_734.html) with gazebo-2.0. The goal would be to put this into gazebo-2.1.
summary.html:
The propshop needs 4 pictures for each model. This pull-request contains a plugin and ruby script that will automatically generate these images.

I found that OGRE <1.9 does not allow anti-aliasing in texture buffers. I put in the necessary changes to support OGRE 1.9, which will create nicer images. Ogre 1.9 is not mandatory.

To try the ruby script:

gzprop <model_directory>

For example:

gzprop ~/.gazebo/models/pr2

A tarball should be created in your current directory that contains the model and a set of images in a meta subdirectory.

This PR is ABI/API compatible with gazebo-2.0. The goal would be to put this into gazebo-2.1.

values.description:
This pull request modifies the "View Center of Mass" option in gzclient to show the moment of inertia as well. The COMVisual is modified to show a box of uniform density with equivalent inertial properties, centered at the body center of mass.

It currently only uses the diagonal elements of the inertia matrix; the off-diagonal elements are ignored. This is documented as a TODO in the code and issue #880.

See [gazebo_models pull request 57](#!/osrf/gazebo_models/pull-request/57/rearrange-inertia-values-on-wooden-beam/diff) for an example of the utility of this feature.

Thanks to @spaepcke for the U/X review.
values.title: Visualize moment of inertia (fix #203)

summary.raw:
This pull request modifies the "View Center of Mass" option in gzclient to show the moment of inertia as well. The COMVisual is modified to show a box of uniform density with equivalent inertial properties, centered at the body center of mass.

It currently only uses the diagonal elements of the inertia matrix; the off-diagonal elements are ignored. This is documented as a TODO in the code and issue #880.

See [gazebo_models pull request 57](#!/osrf/gazebo_models/pull-request/57/rearrange-inertia-values-on-wooden-beam/diff) for an example of the utility of this feature.

Thanks to @spaepcke for the U/X review.
summary.html:
This pull request modifies the "View Center of Mass" option in gzclient to show the moment of inertia as well. The COMVisual is modified to show a box of uniform density with equivalent inertial properties, centered at the body center of mass.

It currently only uses the diagonal elements of the inertia matrix; the off-diagonal elements are ignored. This is documented as a TODO in the code and issue #880.

See gazebo_models pull request 57 for an example of the utility of this feature.

Thanks to @spaepcke for the U/X review.

values.description:
The gazebo_2.0 branch doesn't compile on osx without this fix.

There were several similar fixes made in pull request #660 (GpuLaser_TEST.cc and Camera.cc in 34b5f33).

The source of the bug is an interaction between boost and some of the osx system headers. There some discussion here:

https://svn.boost.org/trac/boost/ticket/5010

My approach has been to workaround by moving Rand.hh to the top of the header list, since I haven't been able to figure out a better fix.
values.title: Fix compilation error on osx (#881)

The source of the bug is an interaction between boost and some of the osx system headers. There some discussion here:

https://svn.boost.org/trac/boost/ticket/5010

My approach has been to workaround by moving Rand.hh to the top of the header list, since I haven't been able to figure out a better fix.

https://svn.boost.org/trac/boost/ticket/5010

My approach has been to workaround by moving Rand.hh to the top of the header list, since I haven't been able to figure out a better fix.
